nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: Setting the Table
nodes.text: You and your co-parent sit across from each other, not in a courtroom but at a neutral table. The goal today isn’t to win — it’s to find the first few agreements that make everyday life calmer.

choices.label: Start with something small and practical.
choices.text: You suggest starting with school mornings — who does what, and when.

choices.label: Start by naming how tense things have been.
choices.text: You say that the last months have been intense for everyone and you’d like less fighting in front of the child.

nodes.speaker: Co-Parent
nodes.title: First Reaction
nodes.text: Your co-parent crosses their arms. “Fine. What exactly do you want to change? Because I feel like I’m carrying most of this.”

choices.label: Acknowledge their effort before proposing a change.
choices.text: You start with: “I see how much you’re doing. I don’t want to erase that. I’d like us to write down who does which mornings so we both know where we stand.”

choices.label: Go straight into your complaints.
choices.text: You reply: “You’re not carrying everything. I’m always adjusting my schedule at the last minute.”

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: Drafting the First Agreement
nodes.text: A draft begins to form: who handles which mornings, when changes must be requested, and how last-minute emergencies are handled.

choices.label: Put the child’s routine at the center of the agreement.
choices.text: You ask: “What schedule would feel calmest for our child? Let’s start there and then see what each of us can realistically sustain.”

choices.label: Focus mostly on what’s convenient for you.
choices.text: You steer the conversation toward what fits your work and social life best, hoping they’ll adapt.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: End of Scene – First Agreements
nodes.text: You leave the table with at least one written agreement — imperfect, but real. For the first time in a while, the next school morning doesn’t feel like a cliff edge.
